discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Looking into the actual YANG file at https://www.yangcatalog.org/yang-search/yang_tree/Cisco-IOS-XR-ifmgr-cfg@2020-10-01 shows that interface-configurations (with an s) is the CONTAINER and interface-configuration (WITHOUT an s) is a LIST

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which type of YANG container is described by the JSON instance provided?

discussion.content: This is state data, not config data. Notice "ro"(read only) in front of every leaf and the module name ending in "-oper"(oparational, not config). State data is retrieved with <get>. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6241#section-1.4. So I think it is B.

The <get-config> operation retrieves configuration data only, while the <get> operation retrieves configuration and state data. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6241#
Based on the Read-Only fields then B seems the more accurate.

Selected Answer: B
The exhibit is a read-only YANG leaf ("ro vlan") therefore is classed as "state" date and not config data. As such the <get> statement is what you need to use to interact with this particular YANG model.

Reference documentation: https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/ask-hank-yang-leaves

All the best.
Ans is B , the module is "oper" for getting data state , thus the GET method would be used here

Selected Answer: B
the model is for operational data > get returns config + oper data , get-config doesnt
this is not a model to modify config since all values are ro

B is the correct
There is no command <get> it is C
I think it's B because of the read only data.

Selected Answer: B

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which NETCONF protocol operation is used to interact with the YANG model?

discussion.content:
I believe the answer is 3: If we take a look to the oficial Cisco Yang Model Library: https://github.com/YangModels/yang/tree/master/vendor/cisco/xe

The below models do exist:
Cisco-IOS-XE-native.yang
Cisco-IOS-XE-ntp.yang
Cisco-IOS-XE-ntp-oper.yang

So somehow the NETCONF <get> must interact with them.
3 cause <get> will get both config and oper data - https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6241

Selected Answer: C
Leveraged Multiple AI to get to the bottom of this. There are 3 models referenced. 
Cisco-IOS-XE-native: Handles general native configurations.
Cisco-IOS-XE-ntp: Manages NTP server configurations.
Cisco-IOS-XE-ntp-oper: Deals with operational data for NTP.

The server section within the <native> element is not a separate model; it is part of the same YANG model. In the given XML, the <server> section is nested within the <native> model namespace, which means it is an extension or a component of the Cisco-IOS-XE-native YANG model.

To clarify, here is the structure:

Cisco-IOS-XE-native: This YANG model includes the <native> element and all its nested elements, including <ntp> and <server>.

Cisco-IOS-XE-ntp-oper: This is a separate YANG model that deals with operational data related to NTP.

Thus, the <get> operation interacts with these two distinct YANG models.

The correct answer is:
B. two
The questions says "model" not "module"...might that be the reason why the suggested answer is A (1) and not C (3) ?

Selected Answer: C
C - 3 cause <get> will get both config and oper data

comments.content: You can still interact with oper modules. You can <get> them just like you can <get> any other module. Technically, this is considered an interaction, and as such, 3 is likely the correct answer.

discussion.content: I think the provided answer is correct because the only "oper" module is NTP in that case.

3. Agreed. Check here: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6020 
"All YANG definitions are specified within a module that is bound to a
 particular XML namespace [XML-NAMES], which is a globally unique URI
 [RFC3986]. A NETCONF client or server uses the namespace during XML
 encoding of data."

comments.content: Also would like to know why C

discussion.content: Can you please elaborate on why
I think it is C

choices.D: Native models are developed by vendors and designed to integrate to features or configurations that are relevant only to that platform.
choices.A: Native models are designed to be independent of the underlying platform and are developed by vendors and standards bodies, such as the IETF.
choices.C: OpenConfig models are developed by vendors and designed to integrate to features or configurations that are relevant only to that platform.
choices.B: Native models are developed by individual developers and designed to apply configurations on platforms.
